title: Port codegen to Rust.
body:
- No more Ruby and Python dependency.
- Much faster, and after removing the globbing for `TextResource`s, even fasterer (~2.1s on my MBP with M4 Max).

title: Fix conversion naming.
body:
These were silently ignored (and still are due to the `serde(flatten)` attribute on the field) and set to `None`.

Should be converted to a non-flattened `enum` to avoid this silent failure in the future.

title: Clean non-breaking spaces.
body: `\s` doesn't include non-breaking spaces, so use the POSIX character class instead.

title: Sort hashes.
body: Don't ignore casing by sorting hash keys by their byte representation, to be compatible with `serde_json`.

title: Use JSON for code generation.
body:
The plan is to convert code generation to Rust, but the `yaml` Gem uses YAML 1.1 while `serde_yaml` is deprecated and uses a mix of YAML 1.1 and YAML 1.2, making the comparison while porting hard.

Also, using JSON seems to be faster in Ruby as well.

title: decode FehlerHisFA01...FehlerHisFA20 as Error type
body: decode error history entries as error types instead of byte array

title: speedup xpath
body: we do not need to search within child nodes if we have a full path

title: add devcontainer
body:
add devcontainer configuration for comfortable edits within vscode
- stick with python 3.9 for now
- update ruby to 3.4

title: fix reading bit based data types
body: the bytes from optolink are already sliced, so do not fail with out of bound reads

title: only renegotiate if the client requests it
body: do not negotiate before calling a command if we have a vs2 connection available

title: fix vs2 protocol negotiation
body:
I managed to get my hands back on this ... :)

returing an io:Error within vs2::negotiate causes failing back to vs1 protocol

title: Make API async.
body:
The previous blocking serial implementation was consistently failing (with timeout) for some commands. The same commands were working fine when debugging via the blocking `TcpStream` implementation over `ser2net`.

Switching to `tokio_serial` (and `tokio::net`) resolves this issue.

title: fix conversion
body:
Fixes conversion in two ways
- If the target data type (`SDKDataType`) is `Byte` the value is always clamped/downcasted to `u8` beforehand.
- Further clamping/downcasting is only applied if the target data type is `Double` and the source data type (`EventTypeParameter`) has the signed `S` prefix.

Signed-off-by: Jens Mueller <tschenser@gmx.de>

title: fix device detection
body:
Vitosoft checks hardware index depending on configuartion setting. As far as I can see the setting value is initialized to false and never set to true.
Also fix upper bounds of hard/software ranges.

Signed-off-by: Jens Mueller <tschenser@gmx.de>

title: add device ident structure
body:
Currently I can't connect as my device is not recognized. You must not filter out all the device revisions. IdentificationExtension and IdentificationExtensionTill form two ranges where the upper byte is the supported hardware index and the lower one the supported software index.

A little bit strange: my device is identified as ID 0x20CB, HX 0, SW 8, but the list of valid hardware indexes is only HX 1. Did you encounter something similar too?

Signed-off-by: Jens Mueller <tschenser@gmx.de>

title: fix some warnings
body: Signed-off-by: Jens Mueller <tschenser@gmx.de>

title: fix build of vcontrol binary
body: Signed-off-by: Jens Mueller <tschenser@gmx.de>

title: fix panicked at 'attempt to add with overflow'
body: Signed-off-by: Jens Mueller <tschenser@gmx.de>

title: fix set command for protocol 300
body: I'm sorry, protocol 300 support contains a typo. This fixes "thread 'main' panicked at 'index out of bounds: the len is 5 but the index is 5'".

title: fix desired flow temperature
body: Correct me if I'm wrong, but from my knowledge the desired flow temperature can be found on byte position 17. Byte position 12 is used for desired room temperature.

title: move used protocol definition to config
add protocol 300 support
body: This pull request adds protocol 300 support to your library. I've tested my changes successfully with a VScotHO1 heater. But as I am unfamiliar with rust and its specific patterns I ask you to review this piece of code carefully.
